description: From on board, equivalent to on- +â€Ž board.

entries.meaning: Carried or used on or in a vehicle or vessel
(by extension, figurative) Being a part of, being included in, participating in
examples: When it comes to security, everybody seems to be as onboard as I am.
James is onboard as a production manager.

entries.meaning: On or in a vehicle or vessel; aboard; on board.

verbs.description: onboard (third-person singular simple present onboards, present participle onboarding, simple past and past participle onboarded)

entries.meaning: (figurative) To become a part of a group; to incorporate (someone) into a group.
(figurative) To begin to use a product or service; to take (someone) on as a new customer of a product or service.
